body:
I tried to build and install neovim with `make && sudo make install`, but the `sudo make install` failed with

```
make  -C .deps/build/third-party
make[1]: Entering directory `/home/dbarnett/projects/neovim/.deps/build/third-party'
make[1]: *** No targets specified and no makefile found.  Stop.
make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/dbarnett/projects/neovim/.deps/build/third-party'
make: *** [deps] Error 2
```

`make install` without sudo failed with permission errors since my user can't write into /usr/local/.

I usually build as a normal user and install as root so that I don't get a bunch of root-owned files written into the build directory. Can the build scripts be fixed to support this workflow?

<bountysource-plugin>

---

Want to back this issue? **[Place a bounty on it!](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/5159319-make-sudo-make-install-fails?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F461131&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github)** We accept bounties via [Bountysource](https://www.bountysource.com/?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F461131&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github).
</bountysource-plugin>

Also worked for me. Try this:

```
rm -rf build .deps
make
sudo make install
```

No joy. I even cloned a fresh git repository and got the same results. I'm seeing this at 644da5a43eb245409a, FWIW.

There could be something weird about my root/user permissions, but I've never seen issues like this before.

@dbarnett What happens if you checkout 2f212ca2ebec9a735c3ae4904fc1a1adbeb5d908 (in other words, right before #1213 was merged) and then 

```
rm -rf build .deps
make
sudo make install
```
Does `sudo pwd` show a different current working directory than where you're running the command from?

Nope, still fails at 2f212ca with those instructions, and `sudo pwd` shows the same directory as `pwd`, the one I'm running the command from. I'll `sudo su` and poke around a little bit and see if I can spot any differences between the build outputs from `make` and `sudo make`â€¦

Some Makefiles are missing for my user (along with lots of other files), and there are some extra .ninja files. I scrolled through the output of `make` and didn't notice anything suspicious.

FWIW, I switched to a new computer and I don't see these issues anymore. They were consistently reproducible on the other machine, but apparently only under weird repro conditions. We can reopen if someone else runs into it.

> FWIW, I switched to a new computer and I don't see these issues anymore. They were consistently reproducible on the other machine, but apparently only under weird repro conditions. We can reopen if someone else runs into it.

In any case, thanks for reporting!

A comment for anyone else who's looking for help on this. I've seen this happen if you do not have privileges to set root permissions in a directory (even with sudo).

For example, an NFS network share. Haven't found a way to get around this so far other than building in a local directory.

> For example, an NFS network share. Haven't found a way to get around this so far other than building in a local directory.

NFS shares can be rather interesting.  Depending on what's hosting it and the configuration, root may not be allowed access (I've worked with several systems configured this way).  You're correct: the only way around this is to build in a local directory.  Another choice would be to not install it into a global location, but to a place you have write permissions instead.  For instance, ~/.local or ~/.local/neovim.
This command fails for me as well. I am not using NFS or any other network share.

I found that as long as I used sudo to compile it worked:

```
sudo -E make deps
sudo make
sudo make install
```
